title: 111_hr5878
content: The Act may be cited as the "Economic Fair Treatment and Job Creation Act of 2010". The golf industry in the United States has approximately 28.7 million players and raises $3.5 billion for charity annually. It also provides 2 million jobs and $61 billion in total wage income. In 2008, the median cost to play 18 holes at public facilities was $28, and there are over 10,000 public golf courses in the country. About 70% of rounds played at PGA facilities are at public courses. The percentage of minority US golfers is 14.2%, while the percentage of minority PGA professionals is 4.7%. Female golfers make up 22.4% of the US total, with only 3.4% of PGA professionals being female. African-American golfers have an average age of 33, Asian-Americans 36, and Hispanic-Americans 31. Participation rates for US households with incomes above $100,000 are 20-30% for both Caucasians and minorities. For households with incomes between $50,000 to $75,000, rates are 19-24% for Caucasians and 8-18% for minorities. The Act allows the use of funds from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 to support job creation and workforce diversification in the golf industry at public golf courses. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 is amended to restrict the use of funds for private entities, excluding casinos, gambling establishments, aquariums, zoos, swimming pools, and private golf courses not related to job creation and workforce diversification. Funds allocated under the Act for golf courses must submit a report to the Comptroller General within 90 days, detailing existing job data and diversity. They must also implement a diversity plan and recruitment objectives for women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in various positions. The Act requires funds allocated for golf courses to report job data and diversity to the Comptroller General within 90 days. They must also implement a diversity plan for recruiting women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities for senior executive positions from various sources. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress by April 1, 2011, regarding the use of funds for golf courses. The report will include baseline data on employment diversity, analysis and recommendations for improving diversity, information on new job creation, and strategies for recruiting women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities for senior positions in the golf industry. SEC. 6 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude tax benefits for private golf courses and country clubs starting from taxable years after December 31, 2009.
